Python Certifi SSL Certificate Guide | Generated by AI

Home 2025.10

The certifi package on PyPI is a small library that provides Mozilla‚Äôs trusted root certificates in a bundle. It‚Äôs commonly used by Python libraries like requests, urllib3, or any HTTPS client that needs to validate SSL/TLS certificates.

Here‚Äôs how to use it:

1. Install certifi

pip install certifi

2. Get the CA bundle path

In Python:

import certifi

print(certifi.where())

This will print the full path to the CA certificate bundle (a .pem file). For example:

/usr/local/lib/python3.11/site-packages/certifi/cacert.pem

3. Use with requests or urllib3

import requests
import certifi

response = requests.get("https://example.com", verify=certifi.where())
print(response.status_code)

By default, requests already uses certifi internally, but explicitly passing verify=certifi.where() ensures it uses the updated bundle.

4. Use in other HTTPS libraries

If you‚Äôre working with urllib3 directly:

import urllib3
import certifi

http = urllib3.PoolManager(
    cert_reqs="CERT_REQUIRED",
    ca_certs=certifi.where()
)

response = http.request("GET", "https://example.com")
print(response.status)

5. System-wide usage (optional)

Sometimes you might want to point an app to use certifi‚Äôs CA bundle:

export SSL_CERT_FILE=$(python -m certifi)

üëâ In short:

  • Install with pip install certifi
  • Use certifi.where() to get the certificate bundle path
  • Pass it to libraries that need certificate validation
